conclusion: Determine the time it takes for light to travel through the prism using optics and geometry.
The prism is isosceles with vertex angle θ = 30°, side length AB = L, and light hits midpoint O of AB at incident angle i = 45°.
Light enters the prism at O and exits perpendicular to AC, making the angle of refraction at the exit point 90°.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where n1 is the refractive index of air (n1 = 1) and n2 is the refractive index of the prism.
At the exit point, sin(r) = 1 because the light exits at 90°.
Light travels from O to exit point on AC; distance OA is half of AB, so OA = L/2.
Calculate height of prism using vertex angle θ = 30°: h = L/2 tan(30°) = L/2√3.
Distance d inside prism is hypotenuse of right triangle formed by height and half the base.
Speed of light in prism v = c/n2 = c√2.
Calculate time of propagation: t = d/v = L/c√6.
The propagation time of light in the prism is L/c√6.
